description: This course introduces students to the history, modes, and aesthetics of documentary film and video, with an emphasis on US-produced works. The first half of the class traces the development of non-narrative film forms from the late 1900s to the early 2000s through two frames: the relationship between film/video, historical events, and social change; and the technological, political, and critical contexts that gave rise to different aesthetic modes in documentary works. The second half of the semester concentrates on topical issues: historical films, womens and gay "liberation" films, black filmmaking traditions, and autobiographical and family films. Each week we will view clips from classic examples of the period/mode/topic, plus one feature-length screening of a recent exemplar. By comparing the historical with the contemporary examples, students can see the legacy of past modes and styles in films made within the last 10 years.
name: HIST OF THE DOCUMENTARY
